posts.text:
> the fact the domain is registered to a name which matches [..] should be a dead giveaway the person is real.

it helps, but imho it's the time gap that really lends credence. Pre-2016 would be better (sockpuppet account creation spiked around that time, trump/russia social media manipulation).

reply_context.text: I can at least say with confidence that the identity "Grant Peace" has an internet footprint going back to at least 2016, and that whoever was operating that identity also has at least ownership of this bsky account. Whether or not that person is creating the content themselves is a separate issue.

posts.text: I can at least say with confidence that the identity "Grant Peace" has an internet footprint going back to at least 2016, and that whoever was operating that identity also has at least ownership of this bsky account. Unless the person has automated their identity using AI, in which case, does not prove I am not an AI on this platform.

posts.text:
I don't know what "cannot be replicated by an AI agent means", but for my own edification, my strategy was to:
* recognize that your bsky identity is registered under a domain name
* looked up the WHOIS entry and found it was registered in 2016, which predates the transformer revolution

posts.text: Talk about The Wire, Sopranos, Game of Thrones all you want, but the greatest US television program ever made is Sesame Street. It's not even close. 50+ years of treating kids across class, ethnicity, religion not as mini-consumers...but as citizens with a stake in this world.

This is a great example of the kind of thing I'm describing. If you're searching journals, you want to take into account the topology of the citation network. If your search platform isn't doing that, it is simply not addressing the user's needs.

reply_context.text: The issues with summarizing are on my mind because I've been trialing various library journal database LLM search add-ons vendors are pushing. They really fall down on that critical part of the task

posts.text: What I'm complaining about is slightly different from the LLM-generated search summary stuff, but I think is absolutely relevant to this conversation.

reply_context.text:
The magic of PageRank was leveraging network centrality (influence) as a proxy for reliability. This permitted google to not just highlight relevant content, but to rank it relative to how trustworthy/valuable the source was likely to be.

GenAI search is complete reversion to relevance only ranking

posts.text:
The magic of PageRank was leveraging network centrality (influence) as a proxy for reliability. This permitted google to not just highlight relevant content, but to rank it relative to how trustworthy/valuable the source was likely to be.

GenAI search is complete reversion to relevance only ranking

reply_context.text: Google search emerged during a period where the internet was being overwhelmed by a kind of "slop": pages that tried to pack in keywords and links to game results. Google rapidly dominated the space because they realized that "relevance" is necessary but not sufficient for search ranking. ...

posts.text: Google search emerged during a period where the internet was being overwhelmed by a kind of "slop": pages that tried to pack in keywords and links to game results. Google rapidly dominated the space because they realized that "relevance" is necessary but not sufficient for search ranking. ...

reply_context.text:
I just don't see the versions as all that different. Less conflating Google's search summaries and LLM-guided search, it's a common issue between products using the same techniques.

(With you on the frustration of how many don't realize LLMs are now often hooked to search engines)

posts.text: Hear hear.

reply_context.text:
I mean it when I say "valid concern." These are reasonable questions to raise, and I support people discussing them.

But having thought about it, my own answer is: a) put our work out in public, b) build whatever norms and infrastructure are needed to do attribution. In that order.

posts.text:
When I was in middle school I devoured books.
When I was in college I majored in philosophy and had to read massive amounts of dense content all the time. No prob.

I am currently 40 and struggle to get more than halfway through a 300 page novel. My brain has been this way for at least 10-15 years.

reply_context.text:
I've been teaching at Princeton over the same period and the drop-off in reading stamina has been staggering.

I'm not sure of the cause -- some blame K-12 shifts to "chunk reading" while others pin it on COVID -- but it's undeniable.

posts.text: I'm explicitly avoiding invoking an explanation that hinges on the presence of subjective experiences like emotion here. The reason I use the term "frustration" here was to invoke dynamical systems theory, i.e. frustration wrt stability.

reply_context.text: Same. I'm proposing that the opportunity for that "click" only exists for systems for which we 1. can characterize some notion of stability (homeostasis) and 2. the system is frustrated wrt that stable state. Returning the system to its stable orbit is identical to need satisficing.

posts.text: Same. I'm proposing that the opportunity for that "click" only exists for systems for which we 1. can characterize some notion of stability (homeostasis) and 2. the system is frustrated wrt that stable state. Returning the system to its stable orbit is identical to need satisficing.

reply_context.text: Organisms have needs which certain elements in the environment can satisfy. Hence, I'm positing some form of analogous primitive organism-environment "click"

posts.text: Through this lens, the focus is shifted to characterizing *dissatisfaction* as a restoring force towards homeostasis. The "feeling of satisfaction" in this light would then be better characterized as an absence of frustration, where frustration could take any of a variety of forms. 2/2

reply_context.text: I think a positive experience exists to which we often ascribe the emotion of "satisfaction", but strictly speaking I'd posit that this is inverted relative to how we should think of a "primitive feeling of satisfaction" i.e Drive Reduction Theory. 1/2

posts.text: I think a positive experience exists to which we often ascribe the emotion of "satisfaction", but strictly speaking I'd posit that this is inverted relative to how we should think of a "primitive feeling of satisfaction" i.e Drive Reduction Theory. 1/2

reply_context.text: Speaking of satisfaction, that's a term I would prefer over "hedonic valence", since "hedonic" is too narrow, especially in light of research into motivation and DA. Is there a primitive "feeling" of satisfaction? Of when, so to speak, the organism key clicks in the environment lock (or vice versa)?

posts.text: I think this is the better framing of the problem. It's easier to measure the current state/trajectory of a system than it is to propose/operationalize interventions. As a consequence, a lot of research ends up manifesting as, "We looked into it and yes: things are bad."
